channel.title: BBC News - UK Politics

item.title: Channel crossings: Migrant boats could be turned back in new UK move
item.description: France is strongly against the tactic, accusing the UK of breaking international maritime law.

item.title: NI Protocol: DUP could quit from Stormont 'within weeks'
item.description: Sir Jeffrey Donaldson also says his party will now boycott most north-south ministerial meetings.

item.title: Don't mix business and public duty, Tory co-chair Ben Elliot told
item.description: Party co-chair Ben Elliot is warned to be "cautious" and avoid lobbying on behalf of business clients.

item.title: Minister: Doubts continue over Army's troubled Ajax armoured vehicles
item.description: Defence minister tells MPs he hopes noise and vibrations problems can be resolved but gives no deadline.

item.title: Labour critical over Tory MPs' Friday Commons suspension
item.description: Three MPs are banned from the Commons after trying to influence legal proceedings involving an ex-colleague.

item.title: Minister defends social care bill reform wait
item.description: Helen Whately admits the changes to the system are "a little way off" but says it is a big reform.

item.title: Boris Johnson accuses charity of airbrushing Winston Churchill
item.description: But Sir Winston Churchill's grandson says his family "unreservedly support" the organisation.

item.title: Starmer should be inspired by Biden over workers' rights - TUC leader
item.description: Frances O'Grady urges Labour to follow the US president in making workers' rights central to its pitch.

item.title: Rio Ferdinand says football is 'sliding backwards' because of racist abuse online
item.description: Rio Ferdinand says football is "sliding backwards" and racism is being normalised by the prevalence of racist abuse online.

item.title: MSPs to vote on Scottish vaccine passport scheme
item.description: The move will mean only fully vaccinated people will be allowed into nightclubs and many large events.

item.title: Sally Challen defence QC leads domestic homicide review
item.description: Sally Challen's murder conviction was quashed after a court heard she had suffered decades of abuse.

item.title: Covid: Boris Johnson concerned over unvaccinated hospital patients
item.description: Boris Johnson says a "higher proportion" of younger people are being affected by the virus.

item.title: Minister admits mistake over Marcus Rashford-Maro Itoje mix-up
item.description: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson confuses the England footballer and rugby player in an interview.

item.title: Green and amber lists could go in travel rules shake-up
item.description: The BBC has been told that the green and amber categories could be removed and replaced with a new system.

item.title: Rob Roberts MP suspended from Conservative Party
item.description: Delyn MP who sexually harassed a staff member has his party membership suspended for 12 weeks.

item.title: Government to shorten HGV driver testing process
item.description: Government to fast-track lorry drivers to alleviate chronic shortage, BBC understands.

item.title: Social care changes at-a-glance
item.description: The government's promising to restrict costs for families - but what is changing and how will it be funded?

item.title: Major changes to cut number of Welsh MPs published
item.description: The Welsh secretary is among the MPs seeing their seats redrawn in the proposals.

item.title: Chancellor Rishi Sunak announces date of Autumn Budget
item.description: It comes as the Treasury asks government departments to identify 5% of "savings and efficiencies".

item.title: Triple lock pension pledge suspended for one year
item.description: It follows government concern that a big rise in earnings would have meant pensions increasing by 8%.

item.title: Scottish government to restart work on case for independence
item.description: The Scottish government had paused its indyref2 plans because of the Covid pandemic.

item.title: Covid: No plans for October lockdown, says government
item.description: Officials deny a newspaper report saying new rules could come in around England's half-term holiday.

item.title: NI Protocol: Further delays for Irish Sea border checks
item.description: The UK's Brexit minister says the move will "provide space for further discussions" with the EU.

item.title: Afghanistan: PM pledges not to abandon UK allies left behind
item.description: Boris Johnson promises help for them to leave safely - but is accused of not showing leadership.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon to set out plans for Holyrood year ahead
item.description: Scotland's first minister will announce her "programme for government" for the coming year at Holyrood.

item.title: Marcus Rashford says child food poverty 'devastatingly' worse
item.description: The footballer urges people to write to their MP as a survey indicates food poverty is worsening.

item.title: NHS to get £5.4bn extra to deal with Covid backlog
item.description: Boris Johnson says the money will "go straight to the front line" in England over the next six months.

item.title: Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle: I've received death threats
item.description: Sir Lindsay Hoyle urges fellow MPs to be "careful" but not to be deterred from doing their job.

item.title: Pensions: What is the triple lock and why has it been 'suspended'?
item.description: The government has changed a policy which determines the annual rise in the state pension.

item.title: Jo Cox remembered in sister Kim Leadbeater's maiden Commons speech
item.description: Kim Leadbeater says she would "give anything not to be standing" in the Commons as she follows her sister as a Yorkshire MP.

item.title: Boris Johnson on need to address NHS wait times
item.description: Boris Johnson says around 9m treatments could be funded by proposed government investment.

item.title: Sir Keir Starmer: Tories putting rich donors ahead of public
item.description: The Tories are putting their "rich mates" ahead of ordinary working people says Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer.

item.title: Starmer: People with broadest shoulders should pay fair share
item.description: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer says working people will have to pay the new social care tax.

item.title: Ian Blackford: This is a regressive poll tax
item.description: The SNP's Westminster leader Ian Blackford has said the Conservatives are "fleecing" Scottish workers.

item.title: Will Boris Johnson’s plan for the NHS work?
item.description: The prime minister believes new funds will tackle the Covid backlog - but refuses to set targets.

item.title: Social care: Will people still have to sell their homes?
item.description: In 2019, the Conservatives pledged no-one should have to sell their home to pay for their care.

item.title: National Insurance: What’s the new Health and Social Care tax and how will it affect me?
item.description: A new health and social care tax is being introduced, Boris Johnson has announced.

item.title: Universal credit £20 drop: 'I'm used to hunger pains'
item.description: Under 25s are losing the biggest percentage of their income when the payments go down in October.

item.title: Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater: Who are the new Green ministers?
item.description: Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater are the first Green politicians to hold ministerial office in the UK.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: Lib Dem leader Ed Davey wants to target Tory heartlands
item.description: Smashing Tory dominance in the party's traditional areas is Liberal Democrats leader Ed Davey's plan. Can it work?

item.title: Levelling up: The seaside town debating what change is needed
item.description: As a report says levelling up plans must consider local views, people in Rhyl debate the changes needed.

item.title: Afghanistan: Who originally supported Trump's deal with the Taliban?
item.description: UK Defence Secretary Ben Wallace now calls it a "rotten" deal but supported it at the time.

item.title: Sent to Halifax: One town's asylum story
item.description: What life is like for asylum seekers in a Yorkshire town - and what locals think about accepting more.

item.title: Woke: Compliment or criticism, it is now fuelling the culture wars
item.description: The surprising history of a term increasingly thrown around in UK political debate.

item.title: Afghanistan: Why can't the UK hold Kabul airport without the US?
item.description: The US and UK have different timetables for the effort to evacuate people from Afghanistan

item.title: Who is Dominic Raab?
item.description: A profile of the foreign secretary, as he comes under fire for his handling of the Afghanistan crisis.

item.title: Boris Johnson feels MPs' anger during Afghanistan debate
item.description: After a year of flat debates, a full Commons proved harder for the PM to navigate, writes Jessica Parker.
